Though many other questions are raised in the petitions, they are not pressed before us. Learned Advocate General for the State of Andhra Pradesh sought to sustain the schemes as approved by the Minister in their entirety.

issues.text: Whether Ch. IVA of the Act is saved by Art. 19(6) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is based upon Art. 19 of the Constitution. The question is whether Ch. IVA of the Act is saved by Art. 19 6  of the Constitution. If Chiva, which provides for the nationalization of road transport services in the manner prescribed, thereunder is not a permissible legislation conferred by Art. 19 6 , it would certainly offend against the fundamental right of the petitioners to do business in motor transport.

issues.text: Whether such a classification offends against the equality clause of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, is whether such a classification offends against the equality clause of the Constitution. Article 14 says The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

issues.text: Whether the variation of frequency of service by the State Transport Undertaking amounts to a modification of a scheme within the meaning of s. 68E of the Act?

arguments.claim: Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, after considering the question, Shah, J., speaking for this Court, observed We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List.

arguments.claim: Ch. IVA of the Act is saved by Art. 19(6) of the Constitution as it provides for nationalization to exclusion complete or partial.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether Ch. IVA of the Act is saved by Art. 19 6  of the Constitution. If Chiva, which provides for the nationalization of road transport services in the manner prescribed, thereunder is not a permissible legislation conferred by Art. 19 6 , it would certainly offend against the fundamental right of the petitioners to do business in motor transport.

arguments.claim: s.68C does not exceed limits of Art.19(6)(ii); enables partial exclusion consistent with Article.

anchor.surface_text: Under this section a scheme may be framed in respect of road transport service in general or in respect of a particular class of such service empowering the State Transport Undertaking to run the said service it may be in relation to any area or route or a portion thereof it may also be to the exclusion of all or some of the persons running the said service in general or a particular class of it.

arguments.claim: Classification between State undertaking and private operators reasonable under Art.14 with rational nexus.

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, is whether such a classification offends against the equality clause of the Constitution. Article 14 says The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.

arguments.claim: Procedure under Ch.IVA accords with principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme so framed is published, with all- necessary particulars, in the official Gazette and also in such manner as the State Government may direct persons affected by the scheme may file objections within the prescribed time the State Government, after considering the objections and giving an opportunity to the objectors or their representatives and the representatives of the State Transport Undertaking to be beard in the matter, may approve or modify the scheme the scheme so approved or modified is published.

arguments.claim: No personal bias by Minister; sub-committee decision only policy, not predetermination.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, in the counter affidavit filed on behalf of the first respondent the contents and authenticity of the reports of the proceedings of the sub-committee published in the Telu daily Andhra Pradesh were not admitted. Even if the sub-committee came to such a decision, it is not possible to hold that it was a final and irrevocable decision in derogation of the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Chief Executive Officer authorized under s.12 RTC Act to publish schemes as ministerial act.

anchor.surface_text: Relevant portions of s. 12 read A Corporation may from time to time by resolution passed at a meeting authorize the Chief Executive Officer or General Manager, or any other officer of the Corporation subject to such conditions and limitations if any as may be specified in the resolution to exercise such powers and perform such duties as it may deem necessary for the efficient day to day administration of its business.

anchor.surface_text: The short question that arises is whether the variation of frequency of service by the State Transport Undertaking amounts to a modification of a scheme within the meaning of s. 68E of the Act. The rule is not so innocuous as the learned Advocate-General of the Andhra Pradesh contends.

arguments.claim: s.68C empowers inclusion of new routes as scheme for any area or route.

holdings.text: Chapter IVA of the Motor Vehicles Act is not ultra vires the powers of Parliament as it falls within entries 21 and 35 of the Concurrent List.

anchor.surface_text: In that case, after considering the question, Shah, J., speaking for this Court, observed We are therefore of the view that Chapter IVA could competently be enacted by the Parliament under entry No. 21 read with entry No. 35 of the Concurrent List. Nothing further

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and accepts the decision in H.C. Narayanappa v. State of Mysore holding Chapter IVA competently enacted under Concurrent List.

holdings.text: s.68C does not exceed the limits of Article 19(6)(ii); Chapter IVA saved as it permits State monopoly complete or partial in road transport services.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, it must be held that s. 68C does not exceed the limits prescribed by Art. 19 6 ii of the Constitution. Re. 3 The next contention is that the provisions of Ch. IVA of the Act, and particularly those of s. 68C thereof, offend against Art. 14

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets Art.19(6)(ii) broadly to allow exclusion complete/partial of citizens; s.68C textual fit within scope for general/particular services/areas.

holdings.text: Provisions of Chapter IVA, particularly s.68C, do not infringe Article 14; classification between State undertaking and private operators reasonable with rational nexus to efficient road transport.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the provisions of Ch. IVA of the Act do not infringe the equality clause enshrined in Art 14 of the Constitution. Re. 4 By the next contention the learned counsel attacks the validity of the scheme on the ground that the Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies reasonable classification test: State better positioned administratively/financially/technically; procedure prevents arbitrariness; follows precedents.

holdings.text: No personal bias established against Minister; procedure under Chapter IVA accords with natural justice; order not vitiated.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it has not been established that the Minister in charge of the portfolio of transport had personal bias against the operators of private buses and, therefore, disqualified himself from hearing the objections under Ch. IVA of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes official from personal bias; sub-committee policy not predetermination; counter-affidavit denies; follows Gullapalli Nageswara Rao.

holdings.text: Seven schemes are separate and independent, each implementable in entirety; not device to circumvent Srinivasa Reddy.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, therefore, see any legitimate objection to the framing of seven separate, schemes. Re. 6 This contention questions the validity of the schemes on the ground that the Chief Executive Officer of the Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation is not

holdings.reasoning_summary: Each scheme framed per resources for full implementation from fixed dates; no piecemeal; Minister confirmed independence.

holdings.text: Chief Executive Officer authorised under s.12(c) Road Transport Corporations Act to publish schemes as ministerial act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore,, hold that the Chief Executive Officer was well within his rights in publishing the said proposed schemes in the Andhra Pradesh Gazette. Re. 7 The next argument turns upon the provisions of r. 4 of the Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Publication ministerial, not decision requiring s.13 authentication; authorised for day-to-day administration.

holdings.text: Approved schemes satisfy r.4 Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules after Minister's modification specifying vehicles per route.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Minister accepted objection, directed separate indication published by Government; satisfies particulars requirement.

holdings.text: r.5 Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Rules void as inconsistent with s.68E requiring full procedure for modifications; notice severable, deleted; schemes otherwise valid.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Variation of frequency is modification under s.68E needing 68C/68D procedure; rule bypasses; severable without affecting schemes.

holdings.text: s.68C empowers State transport undertaking to propose schemes including new routes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: scheme for 'any area or route or portion thereof'; new route is area/route.

holdings.text: Notice on frequency variation deleted; petitions otherwise fail, dismissed with costs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative result of holdings on all issues.
